title: TAUS Data Association: News and Roadmap
segmentation: Good morning still for a little bit behind on time.
Maybe I can catch up a little bit.
I won't give a long presentation better life.
You of the Towse Data Association portal.
Just a few background historical perspective here in November 2004.
Also had a localization World Conference we had as round table meeting with it.
Companies that were kind of experimenting.
You could say at that time with machine translation technology so early adopters got together in the room.
1520 companies roughly and I had the honor of kind of moderating this or this session and it was very enlightening.
Very useful for everybody, so they asked me to continue this kind of form.
And that's how how's the translation automation uses society was established in.
February 2005.
So about five years ago and we held regular meetings.

The executive forms with groups of 4050 people coming together discussing use cases, best practices, technology, Rd Maps, technology briefings all around machine translation, and we extended our agenda a little bit, discussing localization, Business Innovation and.
Older translation technologies, but very often after somebody would have made a presentation, the question came up, but will you share your translation memories?
Can I have your class trees?
So obviously?

I mean I'm talking 2006, 2007 through these years became apparent that the data are the key to success for translation technology to to become really successful, and so I threw the question back to the audience.
Well, are you serious about it?
Would you consider creating some kind of an industry database and industry repository where we upload LFR translation memories?
It makes sense, you know from the desktop where the translation memory tools for first sort of being launched for the individual translator to the enterprise server, kind of in the what is mid 80s.
Late eight.
No sorry early 90s.
So we went to the GM S TMS systems running the translation memories.
For the benefit of the enterprise for the customer on the server now onto industry shared repositories, so every uploads their teams.
Well, that's kind of an challenge there because we've invested in these assets and we just share them with everybody.
But so we spend a couple of meetings discussing that over a period of, I guess, 18 month.
But in July 2008.
The decision was taken.
The money was put on the table.
Funding was made available by about 40 founding members and the Towns Data Association was established as a spinoff of Taos TDI Towers.
Data Association is a not for profit industry driven industry sort of sanctioned organization, so that's that's the background and here we are today.
This is the website of.
Of Tday, but let me just show you the.
Sort of the vision here.
Implementing an industry vision?
Yeah, this is what we talked about at these founding meetings.
And yeah, we broke some new ground.
How do we deal with IP rights?
You know what kind of services which you offer?
Is this thing going to compete with the market and you know all of these questions came up, you know?
Obviously, you know, if I share the value share as well, I mean, that's that's still the most critical question.
You know, that that's the sort of but we settled on the kind of, uh?
Principle of reciprocity.
You upload data, you can download data.
Actually we have implemented sort of factor 10.
You upload 100 words.
You can download 1000 words.
So 1,000,000 words.
Yeah.
So yeah, the more people start sharing, the more beneficial this whole thing will become.
Currently we're at 2 1/2 billion words.
So from July 2008 at the moment the Association was firmly sort of established.
Founded, we started obviously first developing the platform.
Infrastructure getting the hosting contract in place with cloud computing server company and developing the basic services.
Which that was all done about a year later and last October.
Last summer we had a free pooling.
For the members to download as much as they liked, just to test the system.
Because this was a leap of faith.
If we look back to 2 1/2 years there was just anecdotal sort of stories.
They are like him.
More data really helps you.
It helps in terms of terminology.
Work helps in terms of leveraging translation, memory leveraging and certainly helps in terms of training.
New engines or existing engines making them better, but we had no hard evidence.
So last summer we had a free pudding.
And all of the founding members.
Were you able to download as much as they liked and run test with the data.
Unfortunately, you know we got proof that it really helps blue scores went up by 50%.
Leveraging went up by 2535% and the search turned out to be a very helpful tool for.
Translators and support professionals and so on, so.
Here we are about 8 months, nine months into operation.
If you like, we have about 2.6 billion words in the system and more than 300 language pairs.
As you can see, we have.

You know we would like to represent this as the Super cloud for the translation in the street, but they have all these mini class because the data are uploaded by the Members actually also the general public can upload data.
Now you don't have to be a member.
You can share your teams even if you're not a member.
And you have to select an industry category so we haven't quite as sort of a rich database.
You have attributes for industry category.
We have a placeholder for domain and sector, so you can go to levels deeper content type.
So we do have an attribute for content type language pair.
Obviously data owner data provider.
So it's data from trusted sources.
You can always track it back.
Where is it coming from?
And we have a feedback loop.
You know people can give comments on the data on the individual terms or on the translation memory files.
Then we have a rating system.
To see you know which data are you.
Arming Bester, who likes certain data best.
So.
That's the industry vision.
Now let me.
Just take you for a moment if you like to the lifesite, so just a quick look of the.
The founding members.
Some familiar names that some of the people here in the room represent some of the member organizations.
Actually we have a total of about 70 members now company members.
We also have quite a few individual, so professional members translators can join.
We're reaching out to everybody in the global industry and not just in the translations industry.
Anyone can join as long as you agree to the data, provide improving conditions.
There is a very clear legal framework.

Respecting the IP rights, but the IP owners give full sort of usage licenses to the downloaders of the data so you can develop derivative work so you can develop empty engine so you can use it to do translation leveraging.
So it's basically to help the industry at large to produce translations faster, cheaper, and for all of us to be able to translate a lot more content you know.
And we should certainly talk.
Worry about how we can match up with the translators Without Borders, for instance.
So the surface is currently provided, clearly are services that you do not compete with.
Any sort of commercial offering in the market that's not CDA's mission in life.
Obviously we just need to do what nobody else can do, and that is to be that industry sanctioned Buddy where all the data are being hosted.

This does search where anyone can just it's free public service, so it doesn't require membership or registration or.
Anything you can just look up a term.
Let's I don't if people can see it in the back, but you can just go to towersdata.org and try it yourself.
And as you can see, we use a lot of these.
Open source tools gives A plus, plus corpus, workbench tree, tacker and so we produce these computer translations.

English French again.

Proved that the members do get significant benefits out of this.
So people use the data for terminology for translation, memories and for machine translation, training and translation memory.

It's fair to say that a lot of the generally used translation memory tools today are not scalable enough for the high volume data that you can use from the TDI repository or they don't have the kind of advanced we cause Vance leveraging capabilities like in segment phrase based leveraging or corpus based leveraging.
So there is some work to be done in the industry, but I think that was needed anyway.
That translation memory tools are so so behind in terms of where the industry is heading.
So most people today use it for terminology.

The search, the free service, and for machine translation training about 1/3 of our members have downloaded significant volumes already to start training machine translation engines with overall very good results.

But it leads to sort of ideas for new features and services, and there again you know it's not our intent to become a commercial kind of entity that steps into areas where lots of other companies are sort of active.

We are in the terminology area, looking at adding and the multi word translation.
Obviously that's that's a that's a very simple one synonym search purely on statistical basis, identifying.
Related terms and seeing them in the list you know and then being able to translate those terms.
We've done some analysis with TDA members working in exactly the same domain, more than 50% in a particular case of the terminology was different in German.
In this case we looked at German, although relating to the same concept, so the market is getting confused if we have synonyms.
We will be able to tack those terms and find them back anyway.
I will just skip that further and look at the survey we've done.
We've done a public consultation, probably some of you have helped us.
Also figure out what.
We should put on our road map.
The member certainly did.
This isn't indicate this is a summary of the members votes on some of the new features that they like us to add and look at the numbers in the right.
The number one feature that needs to be out of steam cleaning, not that our data are not clean.

They come from trusted sources, their translation memory files, but people have different ideas about well, is clean and there there we have to have some kind of a flexible system that we filter out certain tax.
That we filter out certain.
Symbols or characters and so on to make them cleaner.
Also will be adding again statistical tool that identifies suspicious translation.
So based on alignment dictionaries that would be extracted from all of the tier mix files in the database and alignment dictionary, extract it from the uploaded TM.
Comparing those we've got a match.
It's actually kind of similar to the matching score.
Feature lots there, that's another high priority because people use that top down categorization like my data is in financial.
My data is telecommunications, but there is no tiene file that's unambiguously in that particular industry.
Like you know, we obviously have the EC data in the database, and we've categorized it as professional services, but Oras legal, actually, but it has a lot of financial data.
Alot of other data in there, so the matching scores again will be based on.
Statistical tool to identify the data that are most proximate to your own teams that you're uploading.
So we think you know adding that feature will be a tremendous help for for.
Anyone who's active well in translation, leveraging an empty training.
So that's kind of what's on the road map.
Everything we're using is practical, ready, open source, but we're adding some code here and there.

Data Association becomes like a Taos Technology Association.

Features better on the open source kind of agreement.

Invite all of you to just use that.
I'll search.
There is an API available so you can also integrate that.

It's freely available.

You know, this is the Super cloud of the translation industry for translation.

You're welcome to join.
